passage_text: What it Costs Brace yourself. Most people already know nursing home care can be expensive. Although the average cost is more than $50,000 a year and climbing, it can vary widely depending on where you live. Employee health insurance does not pay for nursing home care. About a third of nursing home residents pay all of their nursing home costs from their own funds

Income Limits. Most states have more flexible income guidelines for Medicaid reimbursement of long-term care. In most states, you can make up to 300% of the SSI income limit and still qualify for nursing-home-only Medicaid. 300% of the SSI limit is $2,130 per month in 2013. Income guidelines for Medicaid may also vary according to the type of long-term care you are seeking

According to the Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation's 2013 Seniors' Housing Report, the average monthly cost of a private one bedroom or bachelor unit that includes at least one meal per day was $1,995. The average monthly cost for private pay heavy care spaces was $3,477 across all unit types.

The cost of living at a nursing home has soared to a new high of more than $80,000 per year. Over the past five years, the median annual cost of private nursing home care has jumped 24% from $67,527 to $83,950, according to Genworth's 2013 Cost of Care Survey, based on data from nearly 15,000 long-term care providers. From 2012 to 2013 alone, the price climbed 4%.
